title: AB 289
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Legislative Employee Whistleblower Protection Act, known as Article 11, allows legislative employees to report ethical violations without fear of retribution. It defines a legislative employee as someone currently employed by either house of the Legislature, excluding Members. Protected disclosure includes filing complaints with the Joint Legislative Ethics Committee or the Senate Committee on Legislative Ethics. The Senate and Assembly have separate committees to address ethical violations by members and employees. An ethics ombudsperson can also receive information about potential violations. The use of official authority or influence includes promising benefits or taking personnel actions. A Member of the Legislature or legislative employee cannot use their authority to intimidate or interfere with a legislative employee's right to make a protected disclosure. Violators may face fines up to $10,000 and imprisonment. They can also be sued for damages in a civil action. This rule does not allow disclosure of prohibited information. Legislative employees can file complaints for reprisal or retaliation within one year of the improper act. The section does not authorize disclosure of prohibited information. Legislative employees can file complaints for reprisal or retaliation within one year of the improper act. A person who engages in acts of reprisal against a legislative employee for making a protected disclosure may face fines and imprisonment. Additionally, they can be held liable in a civil action for damages. In civil actions, once it is proven that protected activity contributed to retaliation against a legislative employee, the burden of proof shifts to the offending party to show the action would have occurred for legitimate reasons. Punitive damages can be awarded for malicious acts, and the injured party is entitled to attorney's fees. Legislative employees can bring civil damage actions without filing a complaint first. Legislative employees can bring civil damage actions without filing a complaint first. A legislative employee is not required to file a complaint before seeking civil damages. Supervisors can take personnel actions based on separate evidence. Former employees can file complaints within one year of the improper act. This article does not diminish the rights of legislative employees under any other law. The article ensures legislative employees' rights are not diminished under any other law. No reimbursement is required for local agencies or school districts due to the creation, elimination, or change in penalties for crimes.
